column3: Pre-term births and long-term impacts in China (2010-2020)
column5: Zhang, Y., Hajat, S., Zhao, L., Chen, H., Cheng, L., Ren, M., ... & Huang, C. (2022). The burden of heatwave-related preterm births and associated human capital losses in China. Nature Communications, 13(1), 7565.
column10: Heat-related morbidity,Maternal and child health,Heat-related deaths,Non-communicable diseases
column15:
'- 25.8% (95% CI: 17.1%-34.5%) of heatwave-related pre-term births (PTBs) per year
- 4609 (95% CI: 711, 6111) PTBs per year
- 62 (95% CI: 9, 82) PTB-related neonatal deaths per year
- 43 (95% CI: 5, 78) PTB-related cases of childhood asthma per year
- 2 (95% CI: 0, 3) PTB-related cases of Type I diabetes per year
- 218 (95%: CI: 34, 290) PTB-related cases of Type II diabetes per year
- 38715 (95% CI: 5972, 51332) PTB-related IQ points lost per year
- 304 (95% CI: 47, 404) PTB-related cases of autism spectrum disorder per year
- 157 (95% CI: 24, 209) PTB-related cases of ADHD per year

column3: Heat mortality in Zurich (1969-2018)
column5: Stuart-Smith, R., Vicedo-Cabrera, A., Li, S., Otto, F., Belesova, K., Haines, A., ... & Ebi, K. (2024). Quantifying heat-related mortality attributable to human-induced climate change. ResearchSquare preprint.
column15:
'- 1,683 (90% CI: 270 − 3,279) heat-related deaths
- 1.4% (90% CI: 0.2% − 2.7%) of all-cause mortality
- 19 heat-related deaths per summer (1969-1985)
- 48 heat-related deaths per summer (2004-2018)
- Adaptation and other changes in impact-temperature relationship prevented 730 deaths.
- 376 deaths due to the top ten highest-emitting fossil fuel companies (Chevron: 59; ExxonMobil: 54; Saudi Aramco: 53; BP: 42; Gazprom: 36; Royal Dutch / Shell: 36; National Iranian Oil Company: 34; Pemex: 23; Conoco Philips: 20; Petroleos de Venezuela: 19)

The Lancet Planetary Health, 8(12), e997-e1009.
column15:
'- 3,583 cases (59%) of heat-related low birth weights (ehLBWs) in southern Asia
- 982 cases (89%) of hLBWs in western Africa
- 2,899 cases (77%) of hLBWs in eastern Africa
- 2,998 cases (53%) of cold-related low birth weights (cLBWs) avoided in central Africa
- 1,068 cases (63%) of cLBWs avoided in southern Africa
- 1,061 cases (65%) of cLBWs avoided in eastern Africa

column15:

column3: Childhood malaria in sub-Saharan Africa (1901-2014)
column5: Carlson, C. J., Carleton, T. A., Odoulami, R. C., & Trisos, C. H. (2023). The historical fingerprint and future impact of climate change on childhood malaria in Africa. medRxiv preprint.
column15:
'- A net increase in the prevalence of childhood malaria (two-to-one odds)
- ~90 excess cases of malaria per 100,000 children (95% CI: -300, 510; 66% chance of positive trend)
- ~630 excess cases of malaria per 100,000 children (95% CI: -40, 1,400; 97% chance of a positive trend) in southern Africa
- ~330 excess cases of malaria per 100,000 children (95% CI: -140, 870; 91% chance of a positive trend) in east Africa
- ~180 excess cases of malaria per 100,000 cases (95% CI: -190, 610; 83% chance of a positive trend) in central Africa
- ~380 fewer cases of malaria per 100,000 children (95% CI: -930, 20; 97% chance of a negative trend) in west Africa

column15:
'- 669 deaths per year (range: -398, 1,773) in the 1960s
- 12,566 deaths per year (range: 3,481, 30,126) in the 2010s

column3: Global mortality from extreme weather (2000-2019)
column5: Newman, R., & Noy, I. (2023). The global costs of extreme weather that are attributable to climate change. Nature Communications, 14(1), 6103.
column15:
'- 60,951 net deaths due to extreme weather events
- 75,139 deaths more likely due to climate change
- 14,187 deaths averted by climate change
- 63% of total economic losses from extreme weather are due to loss of life
- US$1.79 trillion (US$90 billion per year) in economic loss equivalent to loss of life

column15: - 18% of dengue burden is due to climate change; up to 40% in cooler countries

- 241 fewer cold-/cardiovascular-related deaths per year

- 7.9% to 9.7% of heat-related injuries in the 2010s in northern China
- 7.6% to 8.5% of heat-related injuries in the 2010s in southern China

column3: Neonatal deaths in 29 low- and middle-income countries (2001-2019)
column5: Dimitrova, A., Dimitrova, A., Mengel, M., Gasparrini, A., Lotze-Campen, H., & Gabrysch, S. (2024). Temperature-related neonatal deaths attributable to climate change in 29 low-and middle-income countries. Nature Communications, 15(1), 5504.
column15:
'- 175,133 (95% UI: 7,806–353,516) neonatal deaths
- 32% (range: 19-79%) of all heat-related neonatal deaths
- 46% increase in heat-related neonatal deaths
- 457,384 (95% UI: 170,106–868,519) fewer cold-related neonatal deaths 
- 30% (range: 10-63%) reduction in cold-related neonatal deaths
- 168,835 (95% UI: 48,835–296,467) very early heat-related neonatal deaths 
- 29% (range: 8-72%) of heat-related very early neonatal deaths
- 141,322 (95% UI: 2377–339,337) fewer cold-related very early neonatal deaths 
- 35% (country range: 10-69%) reduction in cold-related very early neonatal deaths

column3: Heat mortality in Europe (summer 2022)
column5: Beck, T., Gudmundsson, L., Schumacher, D., Seneviratne, S., Achebak, H., & Ballester, J. (2024). Increasing likelihood of heat-related mortality events with global warming: a continental epidemiological extreme event attribution study. ResearchSquare preprint.
column15:
'- 2022-like extreme heat mortality events have an average return period of eight years (95% CI: 3.6 – 20.8)
- 2022-like extreme heat mortality events are three times (95% CI: 1.02% – 18.6%) more likely 
- 2022-like extreme heat mortality events are 30 times (95% CI: 3.8% – 2,354.2%) more likely in southern Europe
- 2003-like extreme heat mortality events have a return period of 100 years (95% CI: 30.5 – 758.5), compared to a return period of 1,000 years (95% CI: 65.2 – 16,892,749) under pre-industrial temperatures
- 99% of the European population has experienced an increase in the probability of 2022-like temperatures
- The ten regions with the greatest increase in an extreme heat mortality event like the deadliest week in 2022 are all in Spain and Italy
- Heat-related mortality in 80+ year olds is 100 times that of < 65 year olds and 10 times that of 65 – 79 year olds
- Heat-related mortality was slightly higher in women

column3: Heat mortality in a Victoria heat wave (2009)
column5: Perkins-Kirkpatrick, S. E., Selvey, L., Aglas-Leitner, P., Lansbury, N., Hundessa, S., Stone, D., ... & Osborne, N. J. (2025). Attributing heatwave-related mortality to climate change: a case study of the 2009 Victorian heatwave in Australia. Environmental Research: Climate, 4(1), 015004.
column15:
'- 6 +- 3-4 deaths (a 20% increase) attributable to human-caused climate change
- the frequency of a 2009-like event has doubled
- 6 of 8 climate models predicted a statistically significant effect on mortality
